title: RIOT, please answer: Will we get permabanned for scripting if we run LoL through Wine?
body:
I want to permanently switch to Linux, but i've read that some people complained about getting permabanned for no reason just because they used LoL through Wine.

It would be really important to have an official answer for this question.

From what I've read, the support didn't really want to comment or unban all these people because "they generally dont unban scripters" (which is totally fine, as long as the person is actually scripting)

Hey im having a problem running league of legends on linux is there someone you can get to help me ????

The first time I tried to play LoL, was around the time Kalista came out, I think; I did just that--I sent in a ticket to Riot, and the reply they gave me was: "Sorry, we don't do linux; get F'd" basically. There was also some mention of linux users getting tripped by the anti-cheat software, and a further caution to not use it. I think the first account got banned because of just that reason, and the second account I made was just one problem after another. When I would try to submit a ticket on the second account, as soon as 'WINE' or 'Linux' was mentioned, the Riot staffers would shut down, close the ticket, and tell me extremely shortly and usually in a not very pleasant way that they would not help me, and the ticket would be closed.

I was using 2-3 different versions of wine, and using PlayonLinux as the front-end configuration tool, all on top of an LTS version of Ubuntu running a Real-Time Kernel. Usually, I would have to patch it multiple times to get it to work right, and even then, sometimes there would be issues with the in-game store; which occasionally would prevent me from buying items. And after I would spend several hours getting it running okay again, it would be broken by Riot the following Tuesday.

I eventually gave up on playing LoL because it just was not worth it. The tutorial was practically worthless, and did not prepare you to play in a real game at all, and once you got past about level 10 or so, the player base is such a PitA that it really isn't any fun at all. Not to mention that the 'tech help' I got was borderline moronic as they did not really seem to understand how things worked together on a computer, and if you even so much as hint that you are using linux, they absolutely shut down. I think I got one tech support ticket from someone who actually seemed to get how the software works, and was actually helpful and willing to put in a little bit of effort to try to make things work.

I've been a computer pro since the late '90's, and I've watched all of the changes; I switched to Mac in the early 2000's, and after Jobs died, and I saw the impending changes coming to OSX, I basically switched over to linux and open-source entirely. The last laptop I bought had a version of windows on it, and I kept it just so I could play Skyrim, and eventually I figured I would try LoL again--but it's a handicap that I have to reboot in order to do so. I see the day coming where I just won't play any game unless it will work fairly well on Linux, who actually has a growing gaming community because of the work NVidia and Steam have put in. 

I hope riot notices, and eventually makes a linux-native client--even if it only works on one particular desktop or distro.

Upon reading that there were a lot of people getting banned for seemingly running LoL through Wine a tech-savvy friend and myself put this myth to the test.

together we made a dummy account and used his homebuilt PC to run LoL through Wine.

The results?

We didn't even get through the tutorial before leagues anti-cheat system kicked in and banned the account.

So yes, it seems using Wine will get you auto banned and very quickly, whats worse is that Riot seems to support these bans. So alot of innocent people have lost their accounts and it looks like they won't be getting them back.

My sympathies to them.

> [{quoted}](name=Annie x Zoe Yuri,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=IvfO1XEc,comment-id=0003,timestamp=2018-06-12T10:10:22.417+0000)
>
> together we made a dummy account and used his homebuilt PC to run LoL through Wine. 
> We didn't even get through the tutorial before leagues anti-cheat system kicked in and banned the account.

Were there any DLL overrides? Did you install through a manager like PlayOnLinux or Lutris, or did you just run the League installer EXE on the default prefix?

I've heard that there's a new anti-cheat mechanism in the game; perhaps it's being tripped on some Linux configurations. It could be related to which DLLs are actually genuine DLLs (like DX9 installer-sourced) versus WINE-supplied "built-in" versions, which could explain why only some WINE players are being banned, if it's for unexpected responses to whatever test the anti-cheat system is performing.

Anyway, I think the best thing to do about it now is to go on-record before anything happens to one's account. I've been Linux-only for years and currently I'm using Lutris' DX9-based install; it was almost completely hands-off (only some dialogue box clickthrough during installation) and it kinda-works. (The game is fine once going, but it's a bear to get it to launch, and in-game voice has issues.)

I just ordered a new gaming rig basically just for League, so I really hope that I don't have to someday appeal to support over a false positive like some are apparently suffering.

This is exactly my plan; especially after the way Riot has broken the game so shortly after I started playing. I've been giving league a second shot after about a year, and it was fun, but this recent snowballing craze, and the way that any character is viable in any position now is just absolute garbage.

Yes, playing against people better than you is a way to learn how to do things better, but when the whole system is structured to be so fucking unforgiving there really isn't any point in trying. If a player is caught out by just a little bit, and dies, then that sets off the whole chain reaction--it happens a little bit easier next time, but it takes another death or three before you can really learn that it's over and/or accept it. There's no way to learn in an environment like that.

If Riot wants shorter games, then encourage people to play shorter game modes, like 3v# or ARAM or URF. If Riot wants to see more spectacular plays, well; I hate to break it to you, but spectacular plays are by natural law, rare--that's what makes them spectacular. All of this nonsense going on right now is just people snowballing out of control, and there is nothing spectacular about it.

Baldmenace; I will see you in Dota, and other linux-native games.

I have actually been permbanned last week exactly for this. Fortunately, I was not the only one during this time that ended up in such situation, so Riot had a reason to double check this. I sent three support tickets and got unbanned after ~5 days.

Generally speaking, I am playing LoL on Linux since around 2 years. I was using a lot of different setups on two different machines. This was the first time something like this happened to me.

Anyway, the new changes to anti-cheat are going to see the daylight soon and it seems that it might make playing through wine much harder, if not impossible (see [this](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/bug-report/sB4ucqXc-game-client-anti-cheat-changes-going-live) for reference).

However it's just my subjective point of view, if you want, you can ask the same question on [r/leagueoflinux](https://www.reddit.com/r/leagueoflinux/ ). There you can find more people like me and hear their story about playing LoL on Linux.
